'''[[Student activism|Activism]]''' has played an important role in the history of '''[[Ohio Wesleyan University]];'''<ref name="activismreputation">{{cite web |url=http://admission.owu.edu/faqs_whyowu.html#reputation |title=Why OWU |publisher=Ohio Wesleyan University |accessdate=2003-12-05}}</ref><ref name="Hubbart10">Hubbart, p. 10</ref> The founders of Ohio Wesleyan University expressed a hope that the university "is forever to be conducted on the most [[Classical liberalism|liberal]] principles."<ref name="Peabody">Alexander, William M. "Ohio Wesleyan University". ''Peabody Journal of Education'', Vol. 38, No. 4 (Jan., 1961), pp. 200-203.</ref><ref name="liberal">{{cite web|url=http://go.owu.edu/~catalog/cat-a04.pdf |title=The University: Statement of Aims – Intellectual Freedom and Responsibility |format=PDF |publisher=Ohio Wesleyan University |accessdate=2004-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050925114524/http://go.owu.edu/~catalog/cat-a04.pdf |archivedate=2005-09-25 |df= }}</ref> OWU has espoused [[Student activism|activism]] in its academic philosophy.<ref>Tull, p. 40, pp. 127–132.</ref> Alumni of the school have prominently engaged in controversial issues of their times on three central issues—the scope of justice; distributive justice based on race, gender, and income; and institutions related to preserving social structures.<ref name="Hubbart10"/><ref>Tull, p. 132.</ref>
==Early history== [[File:DelawareCountryUGRR.png|thumb|200px|right|The River-to-Lake-Freedom Trail used for transporting slaves generally follows the present-day alignment of U.S. Route 23.]]
On August 5, 1846, the university's first president, [[Edward Thomson]], delivered his [[inauguration|inaugural address]]. He maintained that the college was a product of the [[classical liberalism|liberality]] of the people of [[Delaware, Ohio|Delaware]], and it was fortunate that Ohio Wesleyan was founded in a community divided in religious and political opinions; Thomson believed that the friction of a mixed society prevented [[dogma]]tism and developed energy. The spirit of the college, he said, is the spirit of liberty.<ref name="Hubbart22">Hubbart, p. 22</ref>
Thomson stated in the early days of Wesleyan that a college education should be a barrier to avarice by furnishing "the understanding, the taste, and the perspective that directs us to life's higher purposes ... It would serve political tranquillity, both by accrediting the truly apt candidates for office and by creating citizenry astutely able to assert its liberty against any government's tendency to encroach".<ref>Burtchaell, p. 300</ref>
Thomson was frequently vocal in the national political debates of his time, notably [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] and the [[Manifest Destiny|expansion]] of the United States.<ref name="1850issues">{{cite web|url=http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.cgi?path=231791077249253|title=Roots of Secession: Slavery and Politics in Antebellum Virginia|publisher=University of North Carolina Press|accessdate=2005-10-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050413133931/http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.cgi?path=231791077249253|archive-date=2005-04-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In 1857 he denounced the argument that [[Southern United States|southern]] [[Christianity|Christians]] The [[Underground Railroad]], used as a "transportation system" for anti-slavery activists to free black slaves fleeing from the South to Canada, was extensively utilized in Ohio. In the 19th century, Ohio had one of the most active Underground Railroad operations in the nation.<ref name="underground">{{cite web|url=http://www.ohioundergroundrailroad.org/Marker_Trail.htm |title=River-To-Lake Freedom Trail |publisher=Friends of Freedom Society, Inc. |accessdate=2007-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626115920/http://www.ohioundergroundrailroad.org/Marker_Trail.htm |archivedate=2007-06-26 |df= }}</ref> One of the state's most frequently used corridors on the Underground Railroad passed through Delaware County near Ohio Wesleyan University, now marked along the bikeway trail at U.S. Routes 23 and 36 in the city of Delaware.<ref name="undergroundtrailowu">{{cite web |url=http://www.dot.state.oh.us/dist6/pdfs/UGRR/RTLFT_brochure_web.pdf|title=The River-to-Lake Freedom Trail |format=PDF |publisher=Ohio Department of Transportation |accessdate=2007-02-02}}</ref>
[[Elizabeth Boynton Harbert]] (class of 1864), a [[women's suffrage]] activist, published several books on [[feminism|women's issues]] and suffrage, ''Out of Her Sphere'' and ''The Woman's Kingdom'', and was the chief editor of a women's suffrage newspaper, ''The New Era'', in 1885<ref>Rakow, Lana (1990). ''The Revolution in words: Righting Women 1868–1871'', page 263. Toronto, Ontario: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-25689-5}}</ref> Despite women's suffrage being a controversial issue, Harbert became an associate president of the World's Unity League, vice-president of the Woman's Civic League of Pasadena, vice-president of the Southern California Woman's Press Association, and president of the National Household Economic Association.<ref name="harbert">{{cite web|url=http://oasis.harvard.edu:10080/oasis/deliver/~sch00405 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060902210306/http://oasis.harvard.edu:10080/oasis/deliver/~sch00405 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-09-02 |title=Harbert, Elizabeth Boynton, b. 1845. Series II of the Mary Earhart Dillon Collection, 1870-1939: A Finding Aid |publisher=Radcliffe College |accessdate=2007-01-30 }}</ref>
==Early 20th century: the effect of wars and politics==
<!--commenting this out as the image is redlinked [[Image:RobinsonRickey.jpg|thumb|200px|right|On October 23, 1945, [[Branch Rickey]], an OWU grad, officially signed a contract with [[Jackie Robinson]] for the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]].]]-->
[[Branch Rickey]], a 1903 graduate of Ohio Wesleyan, is regarded as a significant figure in the history of professional [[baseball]] for breaking the sport's [[baseball color line|racial barrier]].<ref name="racialbarrier">{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/content/chronicle/sports/special/barriers/rickey.html |title=Rickey's moral conviction to social progress was mightier than dollar |work=Houston Chronicle |accessdate=2006-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060524170110/http://www.chron.com/content/chronicle/sports/special/barriers/rickey.html |archivedate=May 24, 2006 }}</ref> An racial incident early in Rickey's life when he was as a baseball coach for Ohio Wesleyan in 1910 would play an important role in his decision thirty years later. Rickey's team visited a hotel in South Bend, Indiana, where the hotel manager refused to provide a room for Rickey's black baseball player Charley Thomas. Rickey eventually convinced the manager to allow him to share his own room with Thomas. Rickey recalled Thomas rubbing at his hands, ashamed of the color of his skin and vowed, "Charley, the day will come when they won't have to be white."<ref name="rickeyearlyOWU">{{cite web |url=http://www.jimcrowhistory.org/resources/lessonplans/hs_in_robinson_rickey.htm |title=Branch Rickey and Jackie Robinson: Interview Essa |publisher=Jim Crow Gateway |accessdate=2007-02-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070228095035/http://www.jimcrowhistory.org/resources/lessonplans/hs_in_robinson_rickey.htm |archivedate=2007-02-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 1943 Rickey became president and [[general manager (baseball)|general manager]] of the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]].<ref name="racialbarrier2">{{cite web |url=http://www.hickoksports.com/biograph/rickeybranch.shtml |title=Rickey, "Branch" (Wesley Branch) |publisher=Baseball Hall of Fame |accessdate=2006-12-07 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20061030034113/http://www.hickoksports.com/biograph/rickeybranch.shtml |archivedate=2006-10-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Beginning with the 1946 signing of African American player [[Jackie Robinson]] for the Dodgers, Rickey became renowned for his role in the racial integration of the game. Rickey's feelings on integration were a primary motivating factor in his decision.<ref name="racialbarrier" />
{{quote|text=It is not the honor that you take with you, but the heritage you leave behind.<ref>put source here</ref>|sign=[[Branch Rickey]]|source= OWU class of 1904, former owner of the Brooklyn Dodger Baseball team known for breaking the racial barrier in the sport.}}
In the [[World War I|war years]] of 1917–1919, the break between the United States and [[German Empire|Germany]] struck a military tone on campus. Individual students were volunteering in the [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]], in the [[Canadian Forces]], and other forms of service.<ref>Hubbart, pp. 133–135</ref> As America entered World War I the [[United States Department of War|U.S. War Department]] inaugurated the [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps|Students' Army Training Corps]], a program designed to use existing colleges and universities as training facilities for new military personnel. On the morning of October 1, 1918, about 150,000 college boys on US campuses transformed into student soldiers. This was the induction into the Students' Army Training Corps. In Delaware, on campus, approximately 400 students were given the [[oath of allegiance]].<ref>Hubbart, p. 135</ref> The men received the regular army training and academic instruction prescribed by the Committee on Education and Special Training of the War Department. The mode of student activities changed: campus traditions were put aside, and athletic events were cancelled throughout the fall semester of 1918.<ref>Hubbart, p. 136</ref>
==Campus climate in the swinging sixties== In 1966, students established an [[Upward Bound]] program, funded by the [[Economic Opportunity Act]] of 1964, to help prepare students from lower-income and poverty areas for college.<ref name="upwardbound">{{cite web |url=http://upward.owu.edu/ |title=Upward Bound Program |publisher=Upward Bound Office |accessdate=2005-01-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041211191609/http://upward.owu.edu/ |archivedate=2004-12-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The Arts Castle, the Early Childhood Center, the Big Pal/Little Pal Program, the Andrews House, the Office of Community Service, and the International Ambassador High School Program are among the many programs founded since the 1970s to provide services to the larger community in Delaware.
Elden Smith, Wesleyan's 11th president, appointed a commission in 1968 to study student life and to refine and further edit Wesleyan's previously too-broad Statement of Aims.<ref name="Burtchaell311">Burtchaell, p. 311</ref> The commission's report recommended four criteria that OWU's educators should foster: perception, critical judgement, enjoyment, and active responsibility for the problems of society.<ref name="Burtchaell311" /> On "active responsibility for the problems of society", the report stated, "A socially concerned individual who had no capacity for enjoyment, who exercised glib and trite rather than critical judgement, and who had no perception of reality, would be a public menace. Perhaps this is the meaning of 'do-gooder'. On the other hand, the absence of active responsibility for social problems might degenerate into obsession with self, and that perception might become dilettantism."<ref name="Burtchaell311" />
In 1969, the Commission on Student Life drafted a new form of student life.<ref name="Murchland74">Murchland, p. 74.</ref> It formed the Wesleyan Council of Student Affairs (WCSA) with the right to decide basic policies on matters related to student life.<ref name="Murchland74" /> The group was controversial from the start: more than two hundred students held a sit-in at the student union to gain faculty approval for issues-oriented representation.<ref name="Murchland74" /> WCSA became involved in the first major controversy on the Wesleyan campus in the 1960s: its representatives called for the elimination of academic credit and existence for [[ROTC]] and demanded access to the University's budget and general financial statements.<ref name="Murchland74" />
==Vietnam War and Wenzlau controversy== The escalation of the [[Vietnam War]] in the early 1960s had a significant impact on Ohio Wesleyan students. A small minority had been concerned with the war for several years, but the bombing of [[North Vietnam]] and the [[Gulf of Tonkin Resolution]] in August 1964 raised campus-wide awareness almost overnight.<ref>Murchland, p. 69.</ref> The Vietnam War, so distant, became a huge presence on campus, affected ideas of community, student power, and free speech, and influenced daily decisions like class choices and social interactions. The first stirrings of [[Opposition to the Vietnam War|protest against the war]] occurred in late 1964. In December, the Wesleyan Council of Student Affairs voted to send a letter to President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] opposing the expansion of the war and advocating withdrawal. Opposing expansion was a fairly moderate position, but calling for withdrawal was much more radical.<ref>Murchland, pp. 69–77.</ref>
Wesleyan was the first college campus in the country to demonstrate against President [[Richard Nixon]]'s decision to invade [[Cambodia]] on April 30, 1970.<ref name="Murchland77">Murchland, p. 77</ref> Following the demonstration, two hundred students occupied the Air Force [[ROTC]] building on campus to protest both the war and the awarding of academic credit for ROTC participation.<ref name="Murchland77" /> The ROTC was seen as an extension of the "Pentagon's war machine."<ref name="Murchland77" />
President Wenzlau, then the president of OWU, attempted to disperse the protesters but was shouted down.<ref name="Murchland77" /> The students demanded that the school hold a campus referendum on the issue of ROTC campus disbandment and that the vote be binding on university policy.<ref name="Murchland77" />
Wenzlau called for an emergency faculty meeting on May 1, 1970.<ref name="Murchland77" /> The faculty body, surrounded by more than 300 students, decided to hold a faculty meeting later in the month when the entire faculty body would be present. The faculty meeting authorized sending a telegram to Nixon demanding an immediate unilateral cease-fire for all US troops in [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], and [[Vietnam]].<ref name="Murchland77" />
The student referendum was held on May 22, 1970. The student body was split on the issue of ROTC, while 67 percent voted to censure the [[Vietnam War]].<ref>Murchland, p. 78</ref>
==Involvement in college affairs in the 1970s== OWU students continued to demand more say in university affairs, in addition to making a strong stand on national issues.<ref name="Murchland79">Murchland, p. 79</ref> The Wesleyan Council for Student Affairs and the administration battled over appropriate wording for alcohol and visitation policies. Several hundred students staged a "drink-in" at the MUB (the student union) in 1971.<ref name="Murchland79" /> In the spring of 1971, students set up a tent community called "The People's Park" in front of Sturges Hall to protest housing policies.<ref name="Murchland79" /> Students became involved in decisions on several faculty tenure denials, the academic schedule, and plans for a new gymnasium. Starting in 1970, the Board of Trustees approved a student seat on its board, which was to be filled every three years.<ref name="Murchland79" />
==On racial equality again== Mary King, class of 1963, worked alongside the Reverend Dr. [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] in the U.S. [[civil rights movement]] when she was a young student, and was a member of the staff of the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] (SNCC).<ref name="maryking">{{cite web |url=http://news.owu.edu/2004/mlk.html|title=Mary King |publisher=Ohio Wesleyan University |accessdate=2006-12-07}}</ref>
Reverend Martin Luther King frequently spoke in the U.S. against the [[South Africa]]n government in the 1960s, urging Americans to end [[trade]] and [[investment]]s in that country.<ref name="againstapartheid">{{cite web |url=http://www.novartisfoundation.com/en/publications/proceedings/human/symposium_human_rights/summary/human_rights_apartheid_experience.htm |title=Human Rights and Business: The Apartheid Experience |publisher=Novartis Foundation for Sustainable Development |accessdate=2006-12-07|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061126104537/http://www.novartisfoundation.com/en/publications/proceedings/human/symposium_human_rights/summary/human_rights_apartheid_experience.htm|archivedate= 26 November 2006 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl= no}}</ref> Following political activity by South Africa's blacks in 1985, the government <!--which govt?-->declared a state of emergency.<ref name="againstapartheidemergency">{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/documents/ga/res/42/a42r023.htm |title=Policies of apartheid of the Government of South Africa |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=2006-12-07}}</ref>
The resurgence of campus activism regarding racism existing elsewhere in the world came in response to David Warren's, the 13th president, involvement in the issue.<ref name="Burtch312">Burtchaell, p. 312</ref> In his inauguration Warren stated: "If there is one phrase which I believe best characterizes our Wesleyan education, it is: 'Here I stand.' Within these three words of Martin Luther—'Here I stand'—is compressed the whole of our historical endeavor..."<ref name="Burtch312">Burtchaell, p. 312</ref>
In the 1980s the most organized campus movement was against investments in companies doing business in South Africa.<ref name="Murchland88">Murchland, p. 88</ref> By February 1987, student political action had brought Ohio Wesleyan to pledge to fully [[divestment|divest]] any holdings connected to South Africa.<ref>Tony Vellela(1988). ''New Voices: Student Political Activism in the '80s and '90s''. Cambridge, Massachusetts: South End Press. pp. 20-21, {{ISBN|0-89608-341-1}}.</ref> The OWU Committee on Divestment was organized in 1988 and funded many activities related to its cause. It sponsored an Anti-Apartheid Week, candlelight vigils, and protest marches. One event which drew a lot of media attention was the 1988 demonstration before the Board of Trustees.<ref name="Murchland88" /> Students carried a black and white paper chain as they climbed up the student union ballroom. As their leader announced "Divest!", students broke the symbolic paper chain.
==Recent activism== [[Image:ProtestOWU.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Ohio Wesleyan students Barbara Eldredge and Kit McCann make a social and artistic statement on the steps of the Hamilton-Williams Campus Center.]] Recent years have witnessed activism by student groups on the issues of the [[Iraq War]], [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[globalization]], and women's [[reproductive rights]].<ref name="wesleyanagainstwar">{{cite web|url=http://www.unitedforpeace.org/groups.php?state=OH |title=Local Groups |publisher=United for Peace and Justice |accessdate=2006-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219190325/http://unitedforpeace.org/groups.php?state=OH |archivedate=2006-02-19 |df= }}</ref><ref name="protest">{{cite web|url=http://transcript.owu.edu/033105/topstory2.html |title=Protest pleads for tolerance, diversity |publisher=The Transcript |accessdate=2006-10-15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901203959/http://transcript.owu.edu/033105/topstory2.html |archivedate=2006-09-01 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="wesleyanIRAQ">{{cite web|url=http://transcript.owu.edu/021903/opinion1.html |title=My first protest: This is what democracy looks like |publisher=The Transcript |accessdate=2003-02-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030513202325/http://transcript.owu.edu/021903/opinion1.html |archivedate=2003-05-13 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>Thomas Ehrlich(1988). ''Civic Responsibility and Higher Education''. Washington, D.C.: American Council on Education Oryx Press Series on Higher Education. p. 268, {{ISBN|1-57356-289-0}}</ref>
In April 2002 about a hundred Wesleyan students gathered on [[National Mall|The Mall]] in Washington, D.C. during a weekend of protests for an array of causes, including the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict|Middle East crisis]], and also to denounce lending policies of the [[World Bank]].<ref name="wesleyanagainstWB">{{cite web|url=http://www.islam-online.net/English/News/2002-04/22/article02.shtml|title=Protesters Rally Outside World Bank, IMF Meetings|publisher=Islam Online|accessdate=2006-08-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060722222453/http://www.islam-online.net/English/News/2002-04/22/article02.shtml|archivedate=2006-07-22|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> In February 2003 approximately 100 OWU students travelled to New York City to protest US actions in Iraq<!--the invasion didn't begin until March 19-->, with partial funding from the Wesleyan Chaplain's office.<ref name="wesleyanIRAQ" />
During ''Ohio Wesleyan University Against the War'' <!--which is what? (Cricketgirl)--> on October 5 and November 17, 2004, more than one hundred students held peace rallies in front of Delaware's City Hall.<ref name="wesleyanagainstwar" />
[[File:Citi Bank Activism at Ohio Wesleyan University.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Wesleyan students protesting unfair [[Citibank]] employment policies.]] On March 17, 2005, the Student Union on Black Awareness (SUBA) and the [[College Democrats]] organized a protest on Sandusky Street in Delaware against racial injustice on campus and in the country. University president [[Mark Huddleston]] also participated in the protest.<ref name="protest"/> During his own college years, President Huddleston had mediated between protesters and administration, favoring classic liberal education over brick-throwers.<ref name="OWUHuddlestonprotest">{{cite web |url=http://www.bpdthenandnow.com/1970UBPROTESTS.html |title=Buffalo Police Then and Now. 1970 Violent Protests at University at Buffalo, The State University of New York |publisher=The Buffalo News|accessdate=2005-02-20|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20050403215121/http://www.bpdthenandnow.com/1970UBPROTESTS.html|archivedate= 3 April 2005 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl= no}}</ref>
Academic pursuit and activism have found an intersection in the form of an annual event called The ''Sagan National Colloquium''.<ref name="sagancolloq">{{cite web |url=http://snc.owu.edu/ |title=Sagan National Colloquium |publisher=Ohio Wesleyan University |accessdate=2006-12-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061130224351/http://snc.owu.edu/|archivedate= 30 November 2006 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> Established in 1984, the SNC annually spotlights an issue of concern in the [[liberal arts]] — the impact of [[science]] on [[society]], race and [[reality]], [[censorship]] and [[political power|power]], and the role of [[globalization]].<ref name="sagancolloqabout">{{cite web|url=http://snc.owu.edu/about/ |title=About Sagan National Colloquium |publisher=Ohio Wesleyan University |accessdate=2006-12-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061125175821/http://snc.owu.edu/about/ |archivedate=2006-11-25 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>

{{Infobox ethnic group |image = |caption = |group= Afro-Surinamese people |population= 37% of Suriname's population |popplace= [[Suriname]] ([[Paramaribo]]{{·}}[[Coronie District|Coronie]]{{·}}[[Brokopondo District|Brokopondo]]{{·}}[[Marowijne District|Marowijne]]{{·}}[[Saramacca District|Saramacca]])
[[Netherlands]], [[United States]] |rels= [[Christianity]], [[Afro-American religion]]s, [[Traditional African religions]] |langs= [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Sranan Tongo]], [[Saramaccan language|Saramaccan]], [[Ndyuka language|Ndyuka]], [[Kwinti language|Kwinti]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] }} '''Afro-Surinamese people''' are the inhabitants of [[Suriname]] of [[Sub-Saharan Africa]]n ancestry. They are descended from slaves brought to work on sugar plantations. Many of them escaped the plantations and formed independent settlements together, becoming known as [[Maroon (people)|Maroons]]. They maintained vestiges of African culture and language. == Origins == Most of the slaves imported to Suriname came from [[Central Africa]] (more than 66,900 slaves, 31.6% of the total number), [[Ghana]] (more than 53,000, 25% of the total) and [[Bight of Benin]] (more than 34,700, 16.4% of the total). Thousands of slaves also arrived from [[Senegambia]] (more than 1,300, 0.7% of the total) and the current [[Sierra Leone]] (more than 1,400, 0.7% of the total), [[Windward Coast]] (more than 7,520, 3.6% of the total) and [[Bight of Biafra]] (more than 4,300, 2.1% of the total).{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} The [[Akan people|Akans]] from the central [[Ghana]] were, officially, the predominant slave group in Suriname. However, in practice, slaves from [[Loango Kingdom|Loango]],[https://books.google.com/books?id=UTXE8ZXTVAYC&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=Identidades+en+juego,+identidades+en+guerra,+pagina+49&source=bl&ots=f2EzSDV2ri&sig=ukdBB2svkLP4-2yF7GcQPnoOeQU&hl=es&sa=X&ei=jPfrUbmLGbOQ7AaW4ICIAQ&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Identidades%20en%20juego%2C%20identidades%20en%20guerra%2C%20pagina%2049&f=false Identidades en juego, identidades en guerra] (in Spanish: Identities at stake, identities at war) - Page 49 purchased in [[Cabinda Province|Cabinda]], [[Angola]],[http://www.revista-batey.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=126:mami-wata-diosa-de-la-migracion-africana&catid=9:volumen-iii-2012 Batey: una revista cubana de Antropología sociocultural (in Spanish: Cuban magazine of Culture Anthropology) Mami Wata, Diosa de la Migración Africana] were the largest group of slaves in Suriname since 1670; they surpassed the number on the [[Gold Coast (region)|Gold Coast]] in almost all periods. Enslaved people including the [[Ewe people|Ewe]] (who live in southern Ghana, [[Togo]] and Benin), [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] (from [[Benin]][http://www.publico.es/ciencias/351104/los-genes-narran-la-rebelion-de-los-esclavos Publico.es: Los genes narran la rebelión de los esclavos] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214160036/http://www.publico.es/ciencias/351104/los-genes-narran-la-rebelion-de-los-esclavos |date=December 14, 2010 }} (in Spanish: Genes tell the Revolt of the slaves). Posted by Núñez Domínguez.) and [[Kongo people|Kongo]] (who live in the [[Republic of Congo]], [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] and [[Angola]]), all left their cultural footprints in Suriname. == History== The [[Dutch people|Dutch]] were involved in the slave trade during the early colonial years. They sought office space for their plantations. The space they received was when the British in the [[Treaty of Breda (1667)]] gave land on the northern coast of South America, ceded to them in exchange for [[Province of New York|New York]]. Suriname became a slave colony. Slaves were rapidly shipped from Africa to Suriname to work on coffee and sugar plantations for the Dutch and other Europeans. Over time, the slaves got used to their new environment{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} and they created space for their African religion with many '[[winti]]s', spirits. Some slaves asked their spirits for help with fleeing from the plantation. Thus, every Saturday night under the watchful eye of the plantation owners and black overseers, dance parties were held until late into the night, to the great amusement of the slaveowners. Afro-Surinamese scholar [[Gloria Wekker]] argues, for example, that working-class Afro-Surinamese women retained pre-colonial African cultural understandings of gender, sexuality, and spirituality. She, and other theorists, argue that African cultural retentions are found most often in Afro-diasporic communities that either had irregular contact with dominant groups of the host community or that shielded their cultural retentions from their colonizers. As Wekker observes, Surinamese slaves socialized, communicated, and communed with little white cultural, social, or linguistic interference.Wekker, Gloria. The Politics of Passion: Women’s Sexual Culture in the Afro-Surinamese Diaspora. Columbia University Press, 2006. ==Maroons== Escaped slaves in [[French Guiana]] and [[Suriname]] fled to the interior and joined with indigenous peoples to create several independent tribes, among them the [[Saramaka]], the [[Paramakans|Paramaka]], the [[Ndyuka people|Ndyuka (Aukan)]], the [[Kwintis|Kwinti]], the [[Aluku|Aluku (Boni)]], and the Matawai. Because of their long isolation in interior Rain Forests, they maintained more African culture than did ethnic Africans in the cities. From 1972 to 1978, two American professors, S. Allen Counter and David L. Evans, made seven voyages upriver into the maroon areas. Both African Americans, they wanted to contact these communities and learn about the peoples, to see what African cultures they followed.[http://www.csmonitor.com/1982/0312/031264.html Vincent Harding, "A remarkable search for roots;" ''I Sought My Brother: An Afro-American Reunion,'' by S. Allen Counter and David L. Evans], ''Christian Science Monitor'', 12 March 1982, accessed 2 October 2013 By the 1990s, the maroons in Suriname had begun to fight for their [[land rights]] to protect territory which they had long occupied.[http://www.corteidh.or.cr/docs/casos/articulos/seriec_172_ing.pdf ''Case of the Saramaka People v. Suriname,'' Judgment of November 28, 2007], Inter-American Court of Human Rights (La Corte Interamericana de Derechos Humanos), accessed 21 May 2009 They won an important case in 2007 at the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, which ruled they had rights to their traditional lands. ==Notable Afro-Surinamese people== {{col-begin}}{{col-2}} *[[Alice Amafo]] *[[Boni (guerrilla leader)|Boni]] *[[Remy Bonjasky]] *[[Edson Braafheid]] *[[Ronnie Brunswijk]] *[[Humphrey Campbell]] *[[Romeo Castelen]] *[[Nelli Cooman]] *[[Edgar Davids]] *[[Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink]] {{Col-break}} *[[Ruth Jacott]] *[[Patrick Kluivert]] *[[Anton de Kom]] *[[Melvin Manhoef]] *[[Jan Ernst Matzeliger]] *[[Clarence Seedorf]] *[[Dwight Tiendalli]] *[[Ronald Venetiaan]] *[[Letitia Vriesde]] *[[Jules Wijdenbosch]] {{col-end}} * Georginio Wijnaldum ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ethnic groups in Suriname}} {{African diaspora}} [[Category:Afro-Surinamese| ]] [[Category:People of African descent|Surinamese]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Suriname]] [[Category:Surinamese people of African descent| ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Youth rights sidebar}} The '''age of majority''' is the threshold of adulthood as recognized or declared in law. It is the moment when [[minor (law)|minor]]s cease to be considered such and assume legal control over their persons, actions, and decisions, thus terminating the control and legal responsibilities of their parents or guardian over them. Most countries set the age of majority at 18. The word ''majority'' here refers to having greater years and being of full age as opposed to ''minority'', the state of being a minor. The law in a given jurisdiction may not actually use the term "age of majority". The term typically refers to a collection of laws bestowing the status of adulthood. The age of majority does not necessarily correspond to the mental or [[Sexual maturity|physical maturity]] of an individual.
Age of majority should not be confused with the [[Coming of age|age of maturity]], [[age of consent|age of sexual consent]], [[marriageable age]], [[school-leaving age]], [[drinking age]], [[driving age]], [[voting age]], [[smoking age]], [[gambling age]], etc., which each may be independent of and set at a different age from the age of majority.
Although a person may attain the age of majority in a particular jurisdiction, they may still be subject to age-based restrictions regarding matters such as the right to vote or stand for elective office, act as a judge, and many others.
==Explanation== Age of majority can be confused with the similar concept of the '''age of [[license]]''',<ref>{{cite book|author1=David R. Senn|author2=Richard A. Weems|title=Manual of Forensic Odontology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c9u0MUnexdIC|year=2013|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-4398-5133-3|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=c9u0MUnexdIC&pg=PA212 212]}}</ref> which also pertains to the threshold of adulthood but in a much broader and more abstract way. As a legal term of art, "license" means "permission", and it can implicate a legally enforceable right or privilege. Thus, an age of license is an age at which one has legal permission from government to do something. The age of majority, on the other hand, is legal ''recognition'' that one has grown into an adult.<ref>{{cite book|author=Cornick|title=A Practical Guide to Family Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YcZhqGMFht0C|year=1995|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-314-04451-8|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=YcZhqGMFht0C&pg=PA229 229]}}</ref>
Age of majority pertains solely to the acquisition of the legal control over one's person, decisions and actions, and the correlative termination of the legal authority of the parents (or guardian(s), in lieu of parent(s)) over the child’s person and affairs generally.
Many ages of license are correlated to the age of majority, but they are nonetheless legally distinct concepts. One need not have attained the age of majority to have permission to exercise certain rights and responsibilities. Some ages of license are actually higher than the age of majority. For example, to purchase [[alcoholic beverages]], the age of license is 21 in all U.S. states. Another example is the voting age, which prior to the 1970s was 21 in the US, as was the age of majority in all or most states.<ref>http://www.calbar.ca.gov/Portals/0/documents/publications/Turn-18.pdf</ref> In the Republic of Ireland the age of majority is 18, but one must be over 21 years of age to stand for election to the Houses of the [[Oireachtas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/reference/checklists/checklist_at_what_age_can_i.html|title=At what age can I?|publisher=Citizens Information Board (Bord um Fhaisnéis do Shaoránaigh / BFS)|accessdate=12 January 2011|location=Dublin| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101228220852/http://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/reference/checklists/checklist_at_what_age_can_i.html| archivedate= 28 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Also, in Portugal the age of majority is 18, but one must be at least 25 years of age to run for public office.<ref>{{cite web|title=CONSTITUTION OF THE PORTUGUESE REPUBLIC |url=http://app.parlamento.pt/site_antigo/ingles/cons_leg/Constitution_VII_revisao_definitive.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022091934/http://app.parlamento.pt/site_antigo/ingles/cons_leg/Constitution_VII_revisao_definitive.pdf |archivedate=22 October 2014 }}</ref> A child who is legally [[emancipation of minors|emancipated]] by a court of competent jurisdiction automatically attains to their maturity upon the signing of the court order. Only emancipation confers the status of maturity before a person has actually reached the age of majority.
In almost all places, minors who are married are automatically emancipated. Some places also do the same for minors who are in the armed forces or who have a certain degree or diploma.<ref>[http://www.bostoncoop.net/lcd/emancipation/emancipation_deliverable.pdf Statutory and Judicial Emancipation of Minors in the United States], 2001–2002 analysis by law students of [[Northeastern University]]</ref>
==Civil law== {{Refimprove section||date= September 2009}} In many countries minors can be [[Emancipation of minors|emancipated]]: depending on jurisdiction, this may happen through acts such as [[marriage]], attaining economic self-sufficiency, obtaining an educational [[academic degree|degree]] or [[diploma]], or participating in a form of [[military service]]. In the United States, all states have some form of emancipation of minors.<ref>{{Citation | title = Emancipation of minors | publisher = Cornell | url = https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/emancipation_of_minors}}.</ref>
